I bought a used GTX 1070 Ti for $250 after taxes and shipping off eBay and it runs GREAT.
Keep this in mind. A mined GTX/RTX card is tuned to run on low max power setting (which cuts off boost 3.0) and they overclock them basically creating their own controlled boost clock. They also overclock RAM within stable OEM software limits.
Remember Boost 3.0 will overclock a pascal card 300MHz bone stock as long as temps stay under 80-84C miners effectively make their temp ceiling 50-60C and do a 200-250MHz overclock which means at the end of the day. A mined GTX card is actually safer to buy then a GTX card used for gaming.
If anything the fans might fail down the road... but those are much easier to replace than a new GPU!

I got myself an RTX 2060 Super founders card from Best Buy with my rewards and literally got the card for $295.86, I considered getting the 2070 Super but all of the data suggests that although it's only $100 more the performance isn't $100 better. And for the upgrade from my previous GTX 1060 6gb my PC feels 10 times as strong, even knocking out the Nuclear Submarine category on UserBenchmarks testing software. It plays all titles that I have at max settings 1920x1080 @144hz G-sync enabled with a constant 144fps with no issues whatsoever, seeing as the 2070 Super won't get you the bump in performance you're looking for to play 1440p @144hz max settings I'm just not sure what the point of that card is.

There are a few setups that you can buy for under $1500 now with an RTX 2080 in them and 16gb ram coupled with a smaller boot drive SSD of about 250GB and a 1-2TB SATA. Personally that's about how much I want to spend($1500) and I'm actually thinking of getting a Super GPU because they're nearly 1 year newer than their counterparts. The AMD 5700 XT at $399 is a serious deal and sorta kicks ass at that price for the performance you get nearly rivaling the RTX 2070 Super. The only reason why I'm choosing Super over 5700 XT is that I've always loved Nvidia cards, GSYNC, and the Super cards have a bit more future-proofing with real time ray tracing ability and SSL. The 2070 Super also has NVLink SLI capabilities...which doesn't add that much performance at all though and is pretty much worthless to attempt.

I'd love to find a cheap RTX 2080 Super setup but it anyone can find a cheap RTX 2070 Super setup let me know! I wish the RTX 2080 Ti was cheaper/had a cheap setup but I think the lowest RTX 2080 Ti setup I found was $1999 :(

Why Rx 5700 over a gtx 1080 or 1070 ti ?

Since the prices between Nvidia and AMD GPUs are pretty much the same nowadays, i don't see why anyone would go for the AMD ones. I'm no Nvidia fanboy but i've never had any issues with their products. Rock solid even with tons of abuse, and your every need is covered.
AMD on the other hand....always a problem with some game. Always waiting for drivers. Always some temperature issue. Never handled overclocking very well. Always some missing feature you wish they had. I could go on. That's my experience with ATi/AMD products.

More freedom honestly.

Freesync
More vram
Bigger memory bandwidth
Auto overclocking and downclocking
60c max even on heavy load (Sapphire)
Better performance each update (like 20% over time)
Crossfire (who really cares)

Idk but people should just look at the price unless they want rtx scam. Nvidia is solid but AMD is pretty much the same, people get scared about some internet comments and previous experience.

Any recommendation for production pc? 3D modeling, renderings, lots of Photoshop for paintovers, mattepainting...

Brian Deakin AMD is better for the non gaming stuff. If you‚Äôre going to do some heavy 3D modeling then a good cpu is really important. I‚Äôd recommend a Ryzen 7 as it doesn‚Äôt hurt the wallet too bad, running in at 330$, and is still an absolute BEAST, running the same as an i9 9900k, and costing way less. If you‚Äôre not too caring about price, then go all the way for the 12 core Ryzen 9. It‚Äôs absolutely insane, and just 50 bucks more than the i9 9900k at 500$. If you want to go super budget, you might get away with a Ryzen 5. I‚Äôm no expert and focus more on gaming, but a good price to performance recommendation is the Ryzen 7. Now for gpu, rendering requires an absolute powerhouse. You can get any gpu really. Once again, if you‚Äôre looking for a budget yet powerful gpu, get the amd 5700xt, However if you don‚Äôt really care about price to performance, try the 2080 super or the 2080ti. That‚Äôs top of the line pretty much. But if I were building one, I would probably stick with ryzen 7 and the 5700xt. It completely depends how much money you have available, but I feel like this is the highest you can get before the price to performance isn‚Äôt worth it. For games the ryzen 7 is overkill, but since you are doing 3D modeling, the cpu will be used a lot more for that, so a ryzen 7 should be fine. This should leave you an upgrade path for when amd releases their new cards with 7 nm technology that is supposed to blow NVIDIA out of the market.

- PC case - so no functional reason to go over 50 bucks
- GPU - RTX should not be seen as future proof because as soon the next-gen arrives (in about 6 months from both AMD and Nvidia) existing RTX cards will have laughable RT performance compared to new ones. So I would just look for pure performance in the price range or resolution (1080p - RX580, 1440p - 5700 or even 5700XT, 4K - RTX series 2080 and plus
- CPU - Seems that AMD had a real winner here, better future proof than Intel, so 3600X or 3700X would be my pick.
- RAM - Get at least 16Gb and as fast RAM as you can.
- SSD - On the lower prices, I would go for SATA SSD but higher capacity and on higher-end some Samsung nvme 1Tb + some HD for media and similar. Capacity is more important than actual speed among the SSD. Reliability is important too. So go for trusted brand names.
- PSU (power supply) - go for a trusted brand name, at least Bronze certificate and 450W as a minimum (so you can grow a bit in the future). CPU and especially GPU being the main consumers, buy PSU according to them. Always get some margin.

1:20 I'm assuming this guide is for totally green PC shoppers who aren't upgrading anything, because if you don't already have a good power supply, get one. Can anyone tell me that power requirements are going to force a change in the types of connectors for any foreseeable generation? A high quality, high wattage power supply, much more than what you need, will last you longer than any component in your PC. I don't ever want to hear someone say, "Hmm, do I need a better video card or better power supply?" because you should already have the better power supply and if you don't you should get one. It's not a question. And don't skimp because you'll save money for every future iteration of your PC.

May be not $500, but for $550 you can build a system with 1660, which is far better than non-gaming RX 550 or used RX 580.

M/B - ~$70 cheap B360M or B365M. B360M is better, but you would need to find a way to flash a new BIOS to get 9 Gen support.
CPU - ~$90 Core i3-9100F. which is better than 7600K. Fits well for 1080p gaming, unless you are playing games like Transport Fever, Cities Skylines etc.
COOL - $9 fine cooler, like DeepCool Theta PWM 31 with a copper heatsink base. As cheap as stock cooler, but much better.
+2 x $9 140mm Aerocool intake PWM fans.
RAM - For ~$34 you can get one 8 GB stick 2666 CL19 or 2400 CL16. One stick, as some time after you'll be able to get another same stick to get 16 GB. 8 GB is a little not enough for 1080p gaming.
SSD - $64 500 GB Intel 660p. Enough for OS and a few games.
PSU - $22 Aerocool VS Plus 500W. Cheap, good and more than enough.
CHA - $30 Thermaltake H18.
GPU - $210 KFA2 GF 1660.

For $600 you can get GF 1660 Ti. Add $50 and you can get 6-core i5-9400F, which is cheaper than 3600 and better for gaming. And does not require expensive $70 RAM, so you can get 16 GB for that price.

Basing the GPU solely on budget is fail.  It should be considered for Purpose then budget.  Most GPU's in a price range will work just fine, you may not have all the bells and whistles but when buying on a budget that's your trade off.  I love when ppl say idiotic stuff like "You shoulda got that one instead".  Enthusiasts have destroyed not only the GPU economy but also the purchasing mentality as well.  As long as it works as intended for your purposes then anything you buy is a good decision and that's the most important thing.  Sure having a Titan X would be great but reality dictates even the 2080ti is overkill for most gaming needs.  Price is important on a budget but more so will it work for what you need?  if not then save up and make the build a little later, who knows you may find a hidden gem of a deal on Ebay or such in that wait time.  Just don't slap anything together for the sake of getting it up and running in order to play today or pay now for a low end offering that's not gonna make you happy in the long term.
Wait, they went from "TI" to "Super"?

Ti is the more expensive and better version of the card that is often released around the time of the normal card.
Super is a rehash priced around the same price as the original card.

I got the Asus Arez Striz Radeon Vega 56 for 270 ‚Ç¨, new, of course. Other Vega 56 variants were cheaper, but I wanted the Asus Arez Striz, because it runs quieter than those. I did not take the PSU requirements serious enough, though. Allegedly, manufactures exaggerate these sometimes, but in this case the requirement of a 750 watt PSU wasn't a joke. Sure, the PC did start with my old 600 watt PSU, but when loading Shadow of the Tom Raider or No Man's Sky it crashed and rebooted. So I had to spent another 100 ‚Ç¨ (+ 10 ‚Ç¨ for express delivery) for a new power supply. Together with the new monitor, which was the reason why I needed a new graphics card in the first place, this means I won't be able to afford a holiday this year.  On the plus side, my new power supply (a Corsair RM 850) runs quieter than my previous power supply, too.

Got lucky last week by buying a 'broken' 1080TI for 200‚Ç¨ (220 US-$). The issue was the seller flashed a BIOS from a wrong manufacture to the card (flashed a msi BIOS to a zotac card). It took me 1 week to figure out what was even the cards issue and how to Flash a Video cards BIOS even when the Mainboard don't want to Boot anything while the card was plugged in (even the Mainboards BIOS did not Boot, while the card was attached).

Now the card is fixed. I got rid of my 1060 and my 2070. Now I run fkn minecraft on my fkn 1080ti with fkn 1000+ fps without fkn raytracing :(

Buying used Hardware is a lottery. Sometimes you get broken sh*t.

Buy the best GPU 1 time... sell it after the next comes out but wait a month or so just to make sure there's no major issues with the next gen.... aka RTX launched with some memory issues with Micron, then switched to Samsung memory.. So wait the month, after a month of good reviews then sell your card for a reasonable price... In my case I sold my 1080 Ti for $500, plus he gave me a GTX 980 on top and sold that for $150... Now I have $650 and paid another $650 for the 2080 Ti... Ether way 90% of the time you will pay half off your new GPU...

GPU prices are beyond stupid right now. I wouldn't purchase anything more expensive than a 5700xt or cheaper than an rx 570. The 2070 SUPER AIB cards start at $520, which puts it $110 more expensive than the cheapest AIB 5700 xt model. That doesn't seem super worth it considering there is like a 10% performance difference on average. The 2080 SUPER is really stupid though. You're getting like 20% more performance than the 5700 xt, but you're paying like 40% more. Don't even get me started on the 2080 ti. At the lower end, the 1650 is the dumbest "budget" card I've ever seen and everything cheaper than the 570 isn't worth it. I was personally in the market for a $700ish GPU, but the 2080 SUPER is not a product I want to endorse with my wallet. I'll pick up an RX 5700 xt and wait for competition to come back the the high end, maybe next year. Not trying to hate on Nvidia either, I've only ever owned Nvidia cards. They just aren't offering anything worth considering outside the $200/$300 price range right now imo. The 5700 and xt should probably be like $50 cheaper too tbh, but compared to what Nvidia has on the market, Navi is great value and ultimately what you should probably be comparing everything else $400+ to.

I resent that. I have a 1080 ti in my system for gaming, and a vega 64 for opencl performance. Both Team Red, and Team Green in the same system. I Prefer Team Red drivers. Show me a driver update that doesn't break something, and I'll show you a unicorn.

I love the user interface, wattman is built in, I can apply global, or local profiles easy for games, and I honestly get more problems updating team green drivers these days then team red. I don't even make incremental system backups before installing Radeon drivers anymore. They've clearly re-gained my trust. How you liking those driver security exploits? Me? I'm not.

I'd say at the minimum, they are in the same league, just in different ways.

I've personally had an issue with my windows 10 feature update from 1703 to 1803. Where my dual display set up stopped working, tried to use Nvidia Geforce experience to get the driver, application crashed. Downloaded a newer version of the application on Nvidia's site, ran the newer version of Geforce Experience and selected my GPU, (gtx 1070), then tried to download the driver, application failed and gave some random error. Said fuck it and went to Nvidia's site selected my GPU and manually downloaded and installed the latest drivers for the newer version of windows 10 1803. Dual screen set up worked properly again. But it was an annoying hassle. The drivers worked perfectly, but getting them was a hassle.

The one thing I don't like about a lot of "buyers guides" is that they assume you need to buy everything, and I think in that price range it usually makes more sense to follow a logical upgrade path for whatever basic-tier components you have on hand.

Granted I know that opens up a pandora's box of possibilities to account for, but hear me out, I mean the $500 build here only budgets $100 for a GPU and $79 for the CPU and those are the two key factors that will drive system performance.


Cannibalizing the other stuff, $500 buys you a 2600X/mobo combo and a 1660 Ti. Add $50 if you need to pick up a DDR4 ram kit. Everything else should be compatible, and frankly won't really affect gaming performance.

Maybe you guys could do an Upgrade series with a few common scenarios.

1. The release of latest Nvidia driver 436.02 that brings about up to 23% performance boost in certain games like Apex as I've tested with my 2080; ultra low latency option and integer scaling on RTX cards (which makes 4k 144hz monitor way more legit than ever).

Regarding PSUs: The cards up to 1500$ class here are maxing out out at 250W, add the Ryzen + SSD etc. with 150W and you get about 400W, then add maybe 50-100W headroom. CrossfireX stopped using the bridge years ago... it was deemed there was enough bandwidth available in the PCI lanes to connect the cards that way. Furthermore, with DX12/Vulkan it doesn't matter whether or not you have SLI/CrossfireX bridges or settings enabling it, it just happens, even in mixed brands and versions, Developer permitting that is, its all up to whether they utilize the feature in their game/software.
It was not ditched cuz we don't care, it was ditched cuz it was integrated into DX12/Vulkan basically.

You forget some crucial points.
1. Nvidia's GPUs are better in every category for various reasons. Never get amd gpu until they manage to actually produce a good one.
2. Power consumption - if you are running the PC 24/7 and playing 24/7 don't get super high end hardware unless you want to pay big bill. If you want 1080p gaming no need to buy overkill hardware and you save on your bills. Amd hardware consumes more power so bigger bill.
3. Nvidia GPUs work best with Intel CPUs - you don't have to care that much about RAM and MB compatibility and performance like you have to do with amd CPUs, you don't need more than 6 cores and Intel still provides the best single core performance.


Right now the sweet spot for GPU has 2 choices - it is either 1660ti or 2060 super depending on your setup. 2070 super if you have some extra budget. But for me setup with 2070 super will consume too much power.
@Gintoki Shinichi I don't understand why you are responding with this wall of text when you are wrong and I'm right. You are just confusing people with some meaningless talk. But whatever.

Point 1 is just wrong, have no idea where you got that from. Nvidia is better at some use cases, while AMD is better at others.
Point 2 is just a matter of limiting your framerate to keep gpu usage and power consumption down, the difference will be too small to make any big difference, but obviously if you don't need something faster you should get the cheapest that fills your needs. And AMD Polaris/Vega use more power, but Navi is equivalent to Turing in efficiency so when talking 5700(XT) vs 2060S/2070S they have around the same performance per watt.
Point 3 is also just wrong, GPUs don't work better with any CPU brand in particular, AMD single core performance is superior or identical to all Intels CPUs with the exception of the 9900k that have superior single core performance at stock, OC'd i believe most current unlocked Intel CPUs beat their AMD equivalents in single core performance, AMD CPUs are inferior in latency, which causes the lower gaming performance in many cases. This "you don't need more than X cores" is stupid and no one should ever use it seriously, i bet the people that believed the "you don't need more than 4 cores" when 6 cores was released some years ago would agree.


2060S is a really bad choice if you can get the 5700XT for the same price or the 5700 for cheaper.

What's yalls opinion on buying a used 1080ti for 4-500 VS a 2070 super?

@max ayotte They started that way, but since AMD optimizations work really well with the new compute model of Turing, the RTX cards gained a nice boost.

1080ti is still slightly faster overall, but the 2070 Super does well in all the newer full DX12 games.

@Matthew McKellar okay thanks for the information. I was under the impression that the 1080ti performed about the same and sometimes better than the 2080. And the 2070 super performed on par with the OG 2080. So it seems like a wash? More features if you go rtx?

@max ayotte Looked at the benchmarks again, they are within 4% either direction. If they cost the same the 2070 super might be a better pick. If the 1080 TI is $50 cheaper then go ahead and get that instead.

The better half precision compute of the 2070 Super could make it age better, but it could also age similarly, so deference to the 2070 Super at the same price.
@Matthew McKellar mostly gaming and streaming
Depends, do you do any work or technical hobbies on your computer? If so, the 2070 super is going to be a better pick. If you only game, then the 1080ti is 7% faster.

One thing I'll add to this excellent video is that unless you have a specific use case that requires the best of the best components, the $1000-1500 PC build range is really interesting because it offers great performance for present day games. Because I enjoy building PCs and buying new components, I'd rather spend $1000-1500 every 2-3 years VS $2000-2500 every 4-5 years so that I can upgrade more often. Chances are, CPU gains aren't going to be that great from generation to generation so you could probably get away with simply buying a better GPU from a $1000 base build after a few years than building a whole new system. I recently helped my friend put together a $800 build - we opted for a gently used GPU which saved us a lot of money and he can crush any modern game and gives him a foundation to upgrade the GPU when his starts to show his age. This is why PCs are so great.
I imagine this is just a room in his house that he tells people what to do.

Instructions unclear. I got a GTX 1080 for less than 300 eur (Gigabyte G1). I find new 1660 Tis or RX 5700 non XTs for 400ish and above. 2060 non super for 450ish.



Both cards imho should be within the 250/300 eur price, but both manufacturers ask too much of a premium for those that are after all, midranges as the 1060 or the 480/580 were.

And the 1080 beats either all the above quite well, so I really found it was the best option for me.

As an alternative to the 580, an R9 390 can also be had for about $100. It's got 8GB of VRAM for all that matters at that performance point, but more importantly it otherwise is nearly identical to the RX 580 for what should be around $50 less. As a downside it does consume something like 80W more power but 80W shouldn't be breaking a system's power budget.

As someone who doesn't care about raytracing until it's more widely adopted, I feel like this last generation and a half of cards has been a major letdown. I'm ready to shell out the inflated prices for top-of-the-line consumer cards, but no current Nvidia (or AMD) offerings make me feel like I'd actually be getting my money's worth out of the upgrade.

I've found that for my non-gaming uses, consumer cards from the GTX 1000 series outperform a lot of older Quadros from the 2nd-hand market, and the value proposition made by newer Quadros is a bit shaky. I really want to upgrade a few of my cards, but I feel like right now I'm better sucking it up and waiting until late 2020, which is a shame considering I bought a lot of these GPUs back in mid-2016.

I'm pretty torn between the 2070 super gaming oc from gigabyte at 550 euros or the amd 5700xt red devil. sadly that card has no pricing yet available. i do estimate it will be around 480-500 euro's. yes that card is about 5% away from the 2070 super. but sadly it does oc like shite. since the 5700xt has already has had it's performance squeezed out of it. you can mostly see an improvement of 1 or 3 fps in most cases. while the 2070 super can do easily 8-12 fps. with a good overclock.

@Kappa It's not meant for my main PC. It's for the NES PC build. I think I found some cpu heatsink: Prolimatech Samuel 17 which is 45mm high and comes with no fan allows me to slam a Noctua A20 at the bottom (motherboard must be upside down) and that would cool everything inside to the point I won't need an exhaust fan (maximum overpressure).
Other heatsink I considered are the Scythe Big Shuriken 3 and Noctua L12S (big fan of this two brands).
"Sandwiching" mobo and gpu (regular dual slot single fan in this case) with a riser card isn't my favourite scenario. I would have to pull air out with loads of small annoying fans and maybe drilling holes. The less I will use the Dremel the happier I will be.

Gtx 1080 here still going strong. Not planning to upgrade for at least 2-3 years.

@Karl The Fragr That's false, that's what I was saying. Everything gets outdated much sooner. My 680 got outdated in few years, wasted money. Pointless to waste such money on high end enthusiast cards, better buy **70's since cheaper, and you can upgrade much cheaper, saving up you enough when the next thing hits and games get more demanding.

@BIOSHOCKFOXX You can argue like that, but on the other hand you could also argue that buying a high-end graphics card (like the xx80 or the TITAN series) allows you to go longer without having to upgrade, where buying a lower or mid-end graphics card migh cause you to have to upgrade sooner. But again, it's also dependant on how much money you're willing to spend at what intervals and what kind of performance you're looking for. If you really NEED to have top-of-the-line graphics and don't mind throwing down a grand or two on a card, then high-end might start to make a bit more sense. Meanwhile if you're content with not being able to completely max a game out but still want a good experience, then mid-end might be more your thing. Finally if you just want to be able to play and you don't have much of a budget or just don't want to spend a lot of money, then low-end might be for you.



As for your upgrading conundrum, if i were you i'd probably wait until they launch a new generation of cards next year before upgrading. It's far enough into the year that it probably won't be too long until they announce something new. Made that mistake myself, built a brand new system with my 1080 as sort of a late christmas present for myself, only to have them drop the 1080TI for a similar price a couple of months later. Ended up kicking myself for not waiting a bit longer and having a better card for almost the same price, but oh well. Either way, if you wait and just get something cheap to replace your current card, you'll be able to see what the new releases are about and possibly snag a high-end second hand card for a low price when people sell their old cards after upgrading their own PCs. Just something to consider.
